#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Make Pattachitra

#Text=Considering the medium , the paintings of Odisha can be divided into three categories : painting on cloth or canvas is known as ' Patta Chitra ' ; paintings on walls is called ' Bhitti Chitra ' ; and painting on palm leaf , where art is engraved with a sharply pointed slender piece of metal , namely ' Lekhani ' , is called ' TalaPatra Chitra ' or ' Pothi Chitra ' .
#Text=Pattachitra represents a vigorous style of dexterous play of bold lines and bright hues which is quite captivating to the eye .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Prepare the canvas .
#Text=The process of painting Pattachitra begins with the preparation of the canvas .
#Text=Traditionally , cotton canvas was used , but now most of the Chitrakaras ( artists of Odisha ) use silk cloths since they are much softer than the cotton .
#Text=Dip the cloth in a solution of crushed imli seeds and water for 4-5 days .
#Text=Dry the cloth in the sunlight .
#Text=Layer both sides of the cloth with a paste of chalk powder , imli , and gum .
#Text=Let it dry in the sun again .
#Text=Rub khaddar stone on it to make the canvas smooth .
#Text=Thereafter a specific kind of smooth stone is rubbed on it to make the canvas shine .
#Text=Prepare the colours .
#Text=The artists create a variety of colors from natural elements , though nowadays , synthetic primary colors are used to produce a set of secondary and tertiary colors .
#Text=A white colour is prepared by grinding mollusk and conch shells .
#Text=A stone called Haritala is used for yellow .
#Text=Blue is prepared from indigo .
#Text=Black is obtained by burning the coconut shells or from the lamp black .
#Text=Red oxide stone is used for a red color .
#Text=Draw borders along the four sides of the canvas .
#Text=Bordering a canvas gives a perfect look to the entire art .
#Text=Border may contain two or three lines according to their size .
#Text=Later , the border can obtain a colorful appearance through the detailed work of the artist .
#Text=Draw outlines of the figures with pencil .
#Text=The typical name of this procedure is called ' Tipanā ' ( ଟିପଣା ) , which implies the process of making a well-defined skeletal sketch on the canvas .
#Text=Start filling in the hues .
#Text=Coloring the Pattachitra accommodates various steps .
#Text=The first step is ' Hingula Banaka'(ହିଙ୍ଗୁଳା ବନକ ) , which means filling in red since traditionally red is used for the background of Pattachitra .
#Text=This step alludes the filling colours to the background , anyway .
#Text=Secondly , ' Luga Pindha ' ( ଲୁଗା ପିନ୍ଧା ) , or coloring the attire , is done .
#Text=The body colors are then added followed by coloring of attires .
#Text=Then comes ' Gahana Lagi ' ( ଗହଣା ଲାଗି ) .
#Text=It involves the coloring of ornaments in a chrome yellow shade .
#Text=Artists paint some of the ornaments with whitish yellow to render them pearl-studded look and the other with yellow for gold .
#Text=Add detail .
#Text=During the detailing process , first , thick outlines are drawn , namely ' Mota Kala ' ( ମୋଟା କଳା ) and then finer detailing is done , called ' Saru Kala'(ସରୁ କଳା ) .
#Text=Add fine detail to the ornaments .
#Text=The final step is ' Gahana Kuta ' ( ଗହଣା କୁଟା ) , or adding finer details to the ornaments .
#Text=Artists of earlier times used gold foil during the procedure .
#Text=One can use fluorescent color to add the fine decorative features to the Pattachitra .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If you are a beginner you do n't need to be worried about the above method of preparation of colors .
#Text=You can simply buy synthetic colors available at a market and you can get different shades of colors by mixing those primary colors with each other .
#Text=For example , a combination of red and white gives pink .
